class visuscript.animated_collection.AnimatedCollection

  • kwargs (dict) – Arbitrary keyword arguments to be passed to element_from_var().

property element: Element

The Element for the Var contained by this VarContainer.

element_from_var(var: Var) → Pivot

Initializes a new Element to be used by this VarContainer to represent the contained Var.

This is an abstract method that must be implemented by subclasses. Subclasses should define the parameters that element_from_var requires to properly construct the element.

Parameters:

  • var (Var) – The Var used to initialize the Element.

  • args (tuple) – Arbitrary positional arguments passed through from __init__(). Subclasses may define these as explicit positional parameters.

  • kwargs (dict) – Arbitrary keyword arguments passed through from __init__(). Subclasses may define these as explicit keyword-only parameters.

Returns:

The initialized Element.

Return type:

Element

property var: Var

The Var contained by this VarContainer.

  • kwargs (dict) – Arbitrary keyword arguments passed through from __init__(). Subclasses may define these as explicit keyword-only parameters.

Returns:

Bases: Animation

A LazyAnimation allows the initialization of an Animation to be delayed until its first advance.

A LazyAnimation can be useful when chaining together multiple animations in an AnimationSequence, where the initial state of one object being animated should not be determined until the previous animation completes.

visuscript.canvas module

This module contains Canvas and Scene, which allow display of Drawable and animation thereof.

class visuscript.canvas.Canvas(*, drawables: list[~visuscript.drawable.Drawable] | None = None, width: int | object = <object object>, height: int | object = <object object>, logical_width: int | object = <object object>, logical_height: int | object = <object object>, color: str | ~visuscript.primatives.Color | object = <object object>, output_format: ~visuscript.constants.OutputFormat | object = <object object>, output_stream: object = <object object>, **kwargs)

Bases: Drawable

A Canvas can display multiple Drawable objects at once and provides functionality to output the composite image.

A Canvas can receive Drawable objects with canvas << element

Example using the context manager (recommended):

from visuscript import *
with Canvas() as c:
    c << Circle(20)
    c << Rect(40,40)

Example without the context manager:

from visuscript import *
c = Canvas()
c << Circle(20)
c << Rect(40,40)
c.print()

class visuscript.canvas.Scene(print_initial=True, **kwargs)

Bases: Canvas

A Scene can display Drawable objects under various Animations and Updaters and provides functionality to output the composite image(s).

A Scene can receive:

  • Drawable objects with scene << element

  • Animation objects with scene.animations << animation

  • Updater objects with scene.updaters << updater

Additionally, a scene can run through a single Animation with scene.player << animation

Example:

from visuscript import *
with Scene() as s:
    rect = Rect(20,20)
    s << rect
    s.animations << TransformAnimation(
        rect.transform,
        Transform(
            translation=[40,20],
            scale=2,
            rotation=45))

The global singleton configuration object for Visuscript, which sets defaults for various Visuscript features.

classmethod from_bytes(bytes, byteorder='big', *, signed=False)

Return the integer represented by the given array of bytes.

bytes

Holds the array of bytes to convert. The argument must either support the buffer protocol or be an iterable object producing bytes. Bytes and bytearray are examples of built-in objects that support the buffer protocol.

byteorder

The byte order used to represent the integer. If byteorder is ‘big’, the most significant byte is at the beginning of the byte array. If byteorder is ‘little’, the most significant byte is at the end of the byte array. To request the native byte order of the host system, use sys.byteorder as the byte order value. Default is to use ‘big’.

signed

Indicates whether two’s complement is used to represent the integer.

imag

the imaginary part of a complex number

is_integer()

Returns True. Exists for duck type compatibility with float.is_integer.

numerator

the numerator of a rational number in lowest terms

real

the real part of a complex number

to_bytes(length=1, byteorder='big', *, signed=False)

Return an array of bytes representing an integer.

length

Length of bytes object to use. An OverflowError is raised if the integer is not representable with the given number of bytes. Default is length 1.

byteorder

The byte order used to represent the integer. If byteorder is ‘big’, the most significant byte is at the beginning of the byte array. If byteorder is ‘little’, the most significant byte is at the end of the byte array. To request the native byte order of the host system, use sys.byteorder as the byte order value. Default is to use ‘big’.

signed

Determines whether two’s complement is used to represent the integer. If signed is False and a negative integer is given, an OverflowError is raised.

visuscript.constants.BACKWARD: Vec3 = Vec(0.0, 0.0, -1.0)

A three-dimensional unit-vector pointing backward, i.e. away from the camera.

visuscript.constants.DOWN: Vec2 = Vec(0.0, 1.0)

A two-dimensional unit vector pointing downward.

visuscript.constants.FORWARD: Vec3 = Vec(0.0, 0.0, 1.0)

A three-dimensional unit-vector pointing forward, i.e. toward from the camera.

visuscript.constants.LEFT: Vec2 = Vec(-1.0, 0.0)

A two-dimensional unit vector pointing leftward.

class visuscript.constants.LineTarget(*values)

Bases: IntEnum

Defines the source or destination point method for a Line.

CENTER = 2

Indicates that the source/destination should rest at the center the object.

RADIAL = 1

Indicates that the source/destination should rest on the radius of the a circumscribed circle around the object.

byteorder

The byte order used to represent the integer. If byteorder is ‘big’, the most significant byte is at the beginning of the byte array. If byteorder is ‘little’, the most significant byte is at the end of the byte array. To request the native byte order of the host system, use sys.byteorder as the byte order value. Default is to use ‘big’.

signed

Indicates whether two’s complement is used to represent the integer.

imag

the imaginary part of a complex number

is_integer()

Returns True. Exists for duck type compatibility with float.is_integer.

numerator

the numerator of a rational number in lowest terms

real

the real part of a complex number

to_bytes(length=1, byteorder='big', *, signed=False)

Return an array of bytes representing an integer.

length

Length of bytes object to use. An OverflowError is raised if the integer is not representable with the given number of bytes. Default is length 1.

byteorder

The byte order used to represent the integer. If byteorder is ‘big’, the most significant byte is at the beginning of the byte array. If byteorder is ‘little’, the most significant byte is at the end of the byte array. To request the native byte order of the host system, use sys.byteorder as the byte order value. Default is to use ‘big’.

signed

Determines whether two’s complement is used to represent the integer. If signed is False and a negative integer is given, an OverflowError is raised.

visuscript.constants.RIGHT: Vec2 = Vec(1.0, 0.0)

A two-dimensional unit vector pointing rightward.

visuscript.constants.UP: Vec2 = Vec(0.0, -1.0)

A two-dimensional unit vector pointing upward.

visuscript.updater.run_updater(updater: Updater, duration: float)

visuscript.utility module

Module contents

Visuscript is a vector-graphics-based Animation library for Python.

The core class that drives Visuscript’s functionality is Scene. Refer to the documentation for Scene to see how to create Python scripts from which Visuscript can generate a movie.

To create an video with Visuscript, use the command-line utility, visuscript_cli. If Visuscript was installed using pip, this utility should have been added to the environment’s PATH with the name visuscript. Thus, after having created a Python script, use the following to generate a movie and output it as output.mp4:

visuscript path/to/script.py

If the utility is not added to your PATH, the following works as well:

python3 /path/to/visuscript-root-directory/visuscript/cli/visuscript_cli.py path/to/script.py
